This trade was painful at times, but being mechanical and making adjustments such as rolling, reducing position size, adding positive extrinsic value, and adjusting strikes helped. Leaning long into down moves and short into up moves also played a part in this high volatility trade.

If you have a Tasty Trade account, you can view all transactions on the Tasty Trade follow page. The first slide shows all transactions for this trade with comments. You can see all the transactions there.

You can see all the transactions on the following page. This is my order chains, starting with the 85 put and selling a call against it. I rolled out in time, adjusted the strike, and scalped out of the calls. Trading this position led to a huge move in the stock, which we will explore in the next few slides.
I lost $42 on a trade that ended up being a scratch. It was a big disappointment. Looking at the chart, it justified why I closed the position.
The stock traded from 145 to 100 for a year, creating a 40-point range. I sold a put when the stock was around 105-110.

the 85 strike put I sold was 20 points out of the money, representing a 20% down move. However, the stock dropped from 110 to $60 over the next month and a half, a 50% decrease. This is considered a crash in a single name stock.

My adjustments to the downside are short Delta adjustments, keeping me flat out Delta. The stock has fluctuated from $107 to $118, down to $80, back up to $90, then to $75, and finally to $60 where it has remained. Currently, the stock is trading around $75, showing a 50% range in the past three months. This single name stock is prone to crash type moves.
It is uncommon to see a 50% crash in the market as a whole. This stock experienced a significant drop, with little two-sided action. The stock quickly lost value, resulting in a big loss.
In the past few weeks, there was a potential loss of $2,000 on a position if no action was taken. The implied volatility rank was high at 75, indicating a consistently high volatility underlying.

In the Ivy Rank, you can see the implied volatility of the underlying stock. It has ranged from 80-90 down to 50-60 despite a decrease in stock price. The volatility contracted even as the stock price halved, which was not in our favor.

the trade didn't work out in our favor, but it wasn't necessary for this position. Currently, the IV rank is at 58, indicating 80% implied volatility. There is still plenty of premium relative to the stock price, so selling another put may be an option. IV rank is important to consider for context.

Understanding the actual implied volatility of a product is crucial for assessing the option premium relative to the stock price. An implied volatility of 50-80% indicates ample premium to sell relative to the stock's risk. IV rank is less important in this context.

I prefer selling premium in a zero IV rank product with 60% implied volatility over a 100 IV ranked product with 15% IV. A low IV rank indicates the market expects minimal movement, reducing the risk of the stock and potentially leading to higher returns on capital.

In higher IV products, you have more flexibility when rolling from one month to the next. Low IV products like TLT (15-20% IV) make it harder to move your strike due to lack of premium to offset in the near-term cycle.

Premium in the near-term cycle provides more context around trading actively in higher IV products, making it easier to manipulate risk. Starting with a naked put as the stock dropped from 90 to 75-80, a call was sold against it. Adjustments were made during a choppy period from mid to late October.

In October, there was some choppy trading until early November. I took a position and benefited from it. We had a huge move from around $90 to $60-$70. I closed out the call and went long. It's important to decide whether to be long or short at a certain point.
If the stock has gone down 40-50%, I lean long and stay with the put. If there's a rally, I may go inverted on the position. I'm waiting for a directional move while taking advantage of time decay.

take advantage of time decay. In mid-November to early December, I implement an inverted strangle strategy by buying the guts and selling the wings. This allows me to capitalize on a move higher in the market. I then roll out the position in time, buying back the intrinsic value and rolling to an out-of-the-money strangle.

rolling to an out-of-the-money strangle to adjust risk. The width between my strike and break-even remains consistent. Buying the guts and selling the wings shifts where my risk is. All that was needed was some sideways action.

We started with the 85 strike short put. The stock is currently trading at 75, with lows around 60 or 50. Adjusting our strikes lowers our risk and captures decay and extrinsic value during sideways trading from November to December.
decay capture extrinsic value and get back to scratch on a $1,500 losing position. The goal is to move break-even points closer to the stock price.

If the stock trades sideways, the premium collected becomes more significant. Trading small allows for adjusting strikes and positions easily. For example, starting with a short put and adding or removing legs as needed.
short put is down near breakeven around the stock price.
